awd_titl_txt: I-Corps Node:  Activating the Midwest I-Corps Network
awd_abstract_narration:
This project by the University of Michigan I-Corps Node, one of the founding NSF I-Corps nodes, will expand the founding Node into a comprehensive regional node called I-Corps Midwest. I-Corps Midwest Node brings together the University of Michigan (UM) as the lead institution, and the University of Illinois Urbana Champagne, and Purdue University as partner institutions. This Node is uniquely suited to serve the Midwest entrepreneurial ecosystem by bridging rural communication gaps that typically lead to an uninformed commercial opportunity around research inventions, difficulty in retaining and accessing talent with sufficient breadth of specific and relevant expertise, and instilling customer discovery memory across I-Corps programs allowing entrepreneurial researchers to leverage learning from previous I-Corps teams.

This project will create mechanisms to overcome the consequences of low ecosystem density by building on the existing partner university collaborations and create an active and cohesive network that leverages their collective commercialization pipeline, previous experiences, and connections. The Node will form a deeper understanding of the individual motivations and experiences of the faculty and students as they participate in I-Corps programs. This knowledge will help to continue driving culture change at these institutions and create the innovation human capital needed to move research ideas forward into the marketplace. The Node will create measurements of network activity and the resulting outcomes will provide information on which methodologies are effective and should be propagated to other regional clusters and the nation. This project builds on the previous four years of work by NSF to create collaborations that are critically important for institutions that are not located in entrepreneurially dense areas to reach and prepare individuals to compete on a national and international level.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
The Midwest I-Corps™ Node has focused on enabling the Midwest research institutions to realize the economic and societal potential of projects born in fundamental science and engineering. The Node has delivered training programs and built cross-regional partnerships that accelerated the discovery of industrial needs, with a goal of informing future research, technology de-risking plans, and an associated venture launch strategy. I-Corps provides a framework to bring together experienced mentors, commercial experts, promising technologies, and research talent to formulate ways to address challenges in the Nation’s most advanced industries. The Midwest I-Corps Node measures its impact along four dimensions: Training an Entrepreneurial Workforce, Translating Technologies, Enabling Economic Impact, and Nurturing an Innovation Ecosystem.


Training an Entrepreneurial Workforce

Since its launch in January 2017, the Midwest I-Corps Node has trained 1,533 participants. These trainings have involved participants from 57 institutions from across the nation. For the U.S. to be competitive, we need our most innovative people from all walks of life to feel empowered and trained in the customer-centric, value-driven mindset of NSF I-Corps. For this reason, increasing the participation of women and underrepresented groups in I-Corps has been a priority for the Midwest I-Corps Node. Through outreach efforts, the participation of women and minorities in I-Corps have reached parity with the demographic makeup of the served institutions. 


Translating Technologies

Because each I-Corps team is assessing the potential benefits of a new technology, the number of teams serves as a rough measure of the volume of technologies explored through the program. Since 2017, the Midwest I-Corps Node has enabled 702 teams to explore the commercial potential of their technology. These metrics suggest the vast potential that I-Corps offers in identifying potential uses for federally funded technologies. Once a team finds a fit between the technological innovation and a commercial need, the team works to bring that innovation forward through working with existing companies, providing know-how, patents, talent, or launching their own venture.

 

Nurturing an Innovation Ecosystem

The Midwest I-Corps Node has also continued to pilot new ways to nurture an entrepreneurial ecosystem. The Node has focused on creating a region-wide network of instructors. This enables information about market opportunities and industrial needs to flow across the region more effectively. In addition, the Node has developed remote programming so that innovators from all corners of the Midwest can receive the benefit of the training and be connected to the entrepreneurial ecosystem.


Last Modified: 03/25/2022
Modified by: Jonathan Fay
